prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: RXCJ1504 CO(1-0)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We propose observations of RXCJ1504 at CO(1-0) to map the distribution of molecular gas and its velocity structure on the same spatial scales as cooling X-ray filaments, star formation regions and rising X-ray cavities.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: At the redshift of RXCJ1504 (z=0.215), the CO(1-0) line is in band 3. We require an angular resolution of 0.4 arcsec to map the distribution of molecular gas and its velocity structure on the same spatial scales as cooling X-ray filaments, star formation regions and rising X-ray cavities (see Fig. 2). RXCJ1504 is detected at CO(1-0) in an IRAM-30m observation with a total integrated flux of 3.63 Jy km/s. The CO emission in BCGs roughly traces the dust and the brightest H-alpha emission (Edge & Frayer 2003; Salome et al. 2004). The required sensitivity is dictated by the ability to significantly detect and map broad velocity gas flows, similar to those observed during Cycle 0 in Abell 1835 (see Fig. 1), and during Cycle 1 in PKS0745 (see Fig. 1). The observed gas flows contain a variable fraction of the total gas. For instance, the flow in Abell 1835 involves ~1/5 of the total molecular gas mass with the remainder distributed centrally, whereas in PKS0745 we see three extended gas components with the most massive containing ~1/2 of the total mass and little centrally located cold gas. We assume that roughly ~1/4 of the total flux will be distributed in a flow extending ~2 arcsec from the BCG's centre (see Fig. 1), and hence will be spread across 3 spatial bins. For an integrated flux of 3.63 Jy km/s, one quarter of which is in an outflow spread over 3 spatial bins, each with a linewidth of 300 km/s detected with a SNR = 4, requires a sensitivity of 0.25 mJy. The observed flows in Abell 1835 are spread over 250 - 400 km/s. Therefore binning into 80 km/s velocity channels would give us 3-5 velocity bins across the lines. This requires a 1.86 hr observation, including overheads. RXCJ1504 contains a weak, ~10 mJy nuclear continuum source at this frequency, which will not interfere with the detection of the CO line.

The CO(1-0) line will be covered in a single FDM 1.875 GHz baseband, with dual polarization. We will use the remaining three 1.875 GHz basebands in TDM mode to observe the mm-continuum emission. RXCJ1504 contains a ~10 mJy nuclear continuum source at these frequencies against which we could potentially detect a line-of-sight absorption feature from inflowing or outflowing cold gas. ALMA Cycle 1 observations of A2597 at CO(2-1) have found three deep, narrow (5 km/s FWHM) continuum absorption features with line centres redshifted by a few hundred km/s (Tremblay et al. in prep.). We therefore require the narrow 3.1 km/s velocity channels to search for similar absorption features against the continuum emission. Continuum imaging will determine the strength and morphology of the emission, search for variability and possibly enable a self-calibration of the data.

We require an angular resolution of 0.4 arcsec to map the distribution of molecular gas and its velocity structure of large scale cooling X-ray filaments, star formation regions and rising X-ray cavities (see Fig. 2). The key structures that may have been uplifted by the radio bubbles are expected to lie within the central third of the ALMA primary beam. The largest angular scale of 8.0 arcsec therefore ensures that we should not resolve out any significant structure (Fig. 2). Based on CASA simulations and experience with four targets observed in Cycles 0 & 1 using a similar approach, the proposed observation will provide sufficient uv-coverage to image the extended structure.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: RXCJ1504 CO(3-2)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We propose observations of RXCJ1504 at CO(3-2) to resolve nuclear disks, accelerating gas flows and other small-scale structures lying within a few arcseconds of the AGN.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: At the redshift of RXCJ1504 (z=0.215), the CO(3-2) line is in band 7. We require an angular resolution of 0.15 arcsec to map the distribution of molecular gas in the circumnuclear star-formation and cooling regions and the bases of the rising cavities (see Fig. 2). Although there are no CO(3-2) single dish observations of RXCJ1504, we have estimated the peak and total flux densities based on the observed flux density ratio of CO(3-2)/CO(1-0)~4.5 found for similar systems in Edge (2001) and our earlier Cycle ALMA targets, giving an integrated flux of 16.3 Jy km/s. The CO emission in BCGs roughly traces the dust and the brightest H-alpha emission (Edge & Frayer 2003; Salome et al. 2004). The required sensitivity is dictated by the ability to significantly detect and map broad velocity gas flows, similar to those observed during Cycle 0 in Abell 1835 (see Fig. 1), and during Cycle 1 in PKS0745 (see Fig. 1). The observed gas flows contain a variable fraction of the total gas. For instance, the flow in Abell 1835 involves ~1/5 of the total molecular gas mass with the remainder distributed centrally, whereas in PKS0745 we see three extended gas components with the most massive containing ~1/2 of the total mass and little centrally located cold gas. We assume that roughly ~1/4 of the total flux will be distributed in a flow extending ~2 arcsec from the BCG's centre (see Fig. 1), and hence will be spread across ~9 spatial bins. For an integrated flux of 16.3 Jy km/s, one quarter of which is in an outflow spread over 9 spatial bins, each with a linewidth of 300 km/s detected with a SNR = 4, requires a sensitivity of 0.38 mJy. The observed flows in Abell 1835 are spread over 250 - 400 km/s. Therefore binning into 80 km/s velocity channels would give us 3-5 velocity bins across the lines. This requires a 1.28 hr observation, including overheads. RXCJ1504 contains a weak, ~3 mJy nuclear continuum source at this frequency, which will not interfere with the detection of the CO line.

The CO(3-2) line will be covered in a single FDM 1.875 GHz baseband, with dual polarization. We will use the remaining three 1.875 GHz basebands in TDM mode to observe the mm-continuum emission. We have positioned these continuum spectral windows to avoid regions of increased atmospheric absorption in band 7. RXCJ1504 contains a ~3 mJy nuclear continuum source at these frequencies against which we could potentially detect a line-of-sight absorption feature from inflowing or outflowing cold gas. ALMA Cycle 1 observations of A2597 at CO(2-1) have found three deep, narrow (5 km/s FWHM) continuum absorption features with line centres redshifted by a few hundred km/s (Tremblay et al. in prep.). We therefore require the narrow 1.0 km/s velocity channels to search for similar absorption features against the continuum emission. Continuum imaging will determine the strength and morphology of the emission, search for variability and possibly enable a self-calibration of the data.

We require an angular resolution of 0.15 arcsec to map molecular gas and its velocity structure associated with a possible circumnuclear disk, the base of an outflow, and circumnuclear star formation (see Fig. 2). The key nuclear structures of interest are expected to lie within the central third of the ALMA primary beam. The largest angular scale of 3.0 arcsec therefore ensures that we should not resolve out any significant nuclear structure (Fig. 2). Based on CASA simulations and experience with four targets observed in Cycles 0 & 1 using a similar approach, the proposed observation will provide sufficient uv-coverage to image the extended structure.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: RXJ0821 CO(1-0)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We propose observations of RXJ0821 at CO(1-0) to map the distribution of molecular gas and its velocity structure on the same spatial scales as cooling X-ray filaments, star formation regions and rising X-ray cavities.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: At the redshift of RXJ0821 (z=0.10), the CO(1-0) line is in band 3. We require an angular resolution of 0.4 arcsec to map the distribution of molecular gas and its velocity structure on the same spatial scales as cooling X-ray filaments, star formation regions and rising X-ray cavities (see Fig. 2). RXJ0821 is detected at CO(1-0) in an IRAM-30m observation with a total integrated flux of 6.4 Jy km/s. The CO emission in BCGs roughly traces the dust and the brightest H-alpha emission (Edge & Frayer 2003; Salome et al. 2004). The required sensitivity is dictated by the ability to significantly detect and map broad velocity gas flows, similar to those observed during Cycle 0 in Abell 1835 (see Fig. 1), and during Cycle 1 in PKS0745 (see Fig. 1). The observed gas flows contain a variable fraction of the total gas. For instance, the flow in Abell 1835 involves ~1/5 of the total molecular gas mass with the remainder distributed centrally, whereas in PKS0745 we see three extended gas components with the most massive containing ~1/2 of the total mass and little centrally located cold gas. We assume that roughly ~1/4 of the total flux will be distributed in a flow extending ~2 arcsec from the BCG's centre (see Fig. 1), and hence will be spread across 5 spatial bins. For an integrated flux of 6.4 Jy km/s, one quarter of which is in an outflow spread over 5 spatial bins, each with a linewidth of 300 km/s detected with a SNR = 4, requires a sensitivity of 0.27 mJy. The observed flows in Abell 1835 are spread over 250 - 400 km/s. Therefore binning into 80 km/s velocity channels would give us 3-5 velocity bins across the lines. This requires a 1.5 hr observation, including overheads.

The CO(1-0) line will be covered in a single FDM 1.875 GHz baseband, with dual polarization. We will use the remaining three 1.875 GHz basebands in TDM mode to observe the mm-continuum emission. We expect weak nuclear continuum emission (<5 mJy) and will use the full 7.5 GHz bandwidth to maximize the sensitivity. Continuum imaging will determine the strength and morphology of the emission, search for variability and possibly enable a self-calibration of the data. ALMA Cycle 1 observations of A2597 at CO(2-1) have found three deep, narrow (5 km/s FWHM) continuum absorption features with line centres redshifted by a few hundred km/s (Tremblay et al. in prep.). Anticipating this exciting possibility, we require the narrow 2.8 km/s velocity channels to search for similar absorption features against the continuum emission, search for variability and possibly enable a self-calibration of the data.

We require an angular resolution of 0.4 arcsec to map the distribution of molecular gas and its velocity structure of large scale cooling X-ray filaments, star formation regions and rising X-ray cavities (see Fig. 2). The key structures that may have been uplifted by the radio bubbles are expected to lie within the central third of the ALMA primary beam. The largest angular scale of 8.0 arcsec therefore ensures that we should not resolve out any significant structure (Fig. 2). Based on CASA simulations and experience with four targets observed in Cycles 0 & 1 using a similar approach, the proposed observation will provide sufficient uv-coverage to image the extended structure.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: RXJ0821 CO(3-2)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We propose observations of RXJ0821 at CO(3-2) to resolve nuclear disks, accelerating gas flows and other small-scale structures lying within a few arcseconds of the AGN.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: At the redshift of RXJ0821 (z=0.10), the CO(3-2) line is in band 7. We require an angular resolution of 0.15 arcsec to map the distribution of molecular gas in the circumnuclear star-formation and coling regions and the bases of the rising cavities (see Fig. 2). Although there are no CO(3-2) single dish observations of RXJ0821, we have estimated the peak and total flux densities based on the observed flux density ratio of CO(3-2)/CO(1-0)~4.5 found for similar systems in Edge (2001) and our earlier Cycle ALMA targets, giving an integrated flux of 28.8 Jy km/s. The CO emission in BCGs roughly traces the dust and the brightest H-alpha emission (Edge & Frayer 2003; Salome et al. 2004). The required sensitivity is dictated by the ability to significantly detect and map broad velocity gas flows, similar to those observed during Cycle 0 in Abell 1835 (see Fig. 1), and during Cycle 1 in PKS0745 (see Fig. 1). The observed gas flows contain a variable fraction of the total gas. For instance, the flow in Abell 1835 involves ~1/5 of the total molecular gas mass with the remainder distributed centrally, whereas in PKS0745 we see three extended gas components with the most massive containing ~1/2 of the total mass and little centrally located cold gas. We assume that roughly ~1/4 of the total flux will be distributed in a flow extending ~2 arcsec from the BCG's centre (see Fig. 1), and hence will be spread across ~20 spatial bins. For an integrated flux of 28.8 Jy km/s, one quarter of which is in an outflow spread over 20 spatial bins, each with a linewidth of 300 km/s detected with a SNR = 4, requires a sensitivity of 0.30 mJy. The observed flows in Abell 1835 are spread over 250 - 400 km/s. Therefore binning into 80 km/s velocity channels would give us 3-5 velocity bins across the lines. This requires a 1.82 hr observation, including overheads.

The CO(3-2) line will be covered in a single FDM 1.875 GHz baseband, with dual polarization. We will use the remaining three 1.875 GHz basebands in TDM mode to observe the mm-continuum emission. We have positioned these continuum spectral windows to avoid regions of increased atmospheric absorption in band 7. We expect weak nuclear continuum emission (<5 mJy) and will use the full 7.5 GHz bandwidth to maximize the sensitivity. Continuum imaging will determine the strength and morphology of the emission, search for variability and possibly enable a self-calibration of the data. ALMA Cycle 1 observations of A2597 at CO(2-1) have found three deep, narrow (5 km/s FWHM) continuum absorption features with line centres redshifted by a few hundred km/s (Tremblay et al. in prep.). Anticipating this exciting possibility, we therefore require the narrow 0.9 km/s velocity channels to search for similar absorption features against the continuum emission. Continuum imaging will determine the strength and morphology of the emission, search for variability and possibly enable a self-calibration of the data.

We require an angular resolution of 0.15 arcsec to map molecular gas and its velocity structure associated with a possible circumnuclear disk, the base of an outflow, and circumnuclear star formation (see Fig. 2). The key nuclear structures of interest are expected to lie within the central third of the ALMA primary beam. The largest angular scale of 3.0 arcsec therefore ensures that we should not resolve out any significant nuclear structure (Fig. 2). Based on CASA simulations and experience with four targets observed in Cycles 0 & 1 using a similar approach, the proposed observation will provide sufficient uv-coverage to image the extended structure.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: ALMA has revealed at least two surprises in the cores of X-ray clusters. First, radio AGN drive massive molecular gas flows in galaxies. Second, ALMA has identified a new population of slowly moving molecular clouds in massive galaxies that defies explanation. We propose to address this and other science using ALMA CO (3-2) and CO (1-0) observations of two brightest cluster galaxies harbouring powerful radio AGN, molecular gas masses exceeding ten billion solar masses, and star formation rates of up to 140 solar masses per year. The results will bear new and significant developments in our understanding of radio-mode feedback, which is common to all elliptical galaxies and may be a significant factor in shedding elliptical galaxies of their molecular gas, keeping them "red and dead."
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2011.0.00374.S, Molecular gas and feedback in the cores of galaxy clusters, PI McNamara 2012.1.00837.S, Understanding molecular gas acretion and feedback from supermassive black holes, PI McNamara, 2013.1.00531.S
